At that time, there was a bhikshu in the assembly named Chan Nan Ti - he had long ago penetrated deep dhyana samadhi, attained arhatship, the three insights and six spiritual powers, and was endowed with the eight liberations. He immediately rose from his seat, adjusted his robes, put his palms together, knelt for a long time, and said to the Buddha:
The TathÄgata is now in the world, benefiting all.

After the Buddha's nirvÄá¹‡a, when the Buddha is no longer present, if the fourfold assembly has karmic hindrances and when they focus their thoughts, the objects do not appear before them, and thus they have afflictions and all kinds of offenses, from minor offenses up to grave offenses, and wish to repent, how should they eliminate these offenses?
If there are people who kill, hold wrong views, and wish to cultivate right mindfulness, how should they eliminate the evil afflictions and hindrances of wrong views and killing?
Having said this, like a great mountain collapsing, he prostrated with his whole body and bowed his head at the Buddha's feet. He further said to the Buddha:
I only wish that the World-Honored One would explain it for me, enabling all sentient beings in the future to always attain right mindfulness and not part from the sages.
At that time, the World-Honored One, like a loving father comforting his child, said:ğŸ”½Excellent, excellent!
Good man!
You practice loving-kindness, born together with loving-kindness, now endowed with great compassion, the roots of goodness, powers, and the path of enlightenment.
Today, for the sake of all sentient beings in the future, you ask about the Dharma for eliminating offenses. Listen carefully, listen carefully, and consider it well.
At that time, the World-Honored One emitted light from the crown of his head.
This light was golden in color, with five hundred transformed Buddhas circling the Buddha seven times, illuminating Jetavana Grove, also making it golden in color.
After manifesting this sign, it returned and entered the Buddha's skull.
At that time, the World-Honored One told Chan Nanti and ordered Ananda:
You should teach future sentient beings with many offenses, for the sake of eliminating offenses, to contemplate the Buddha.
Because of contemplating the Buddha, they will eliminate the obstacles of karma, the obstacles of retribution, and the obstacles of afflictions.

Those who contemplate the Buddha should first sit upright, join their palms, close their eyes, raise their tongues to touch the palate, focus their minds single-pointedly, and let their minds merge with each other to prevent dispersion.
When the mind is settled, one should first contemplate the image.

Contemplating the image means to arouse thoughts and contemplate the ground in front, making it extremely pure and white. Take the characteristics of the length and width to be two zhang, making it even brighter and purer like a clear mirror.

Having seen the ground in front, see the ground on the left side also to be bright and pure, see the ground on the right side also to be bright and pure, and see the ground behind also to be bright and pure, making the four directions of the ground as flat as the palm of the hand.
In each of the four directions, imagine the ground to be two zhang, making it extremely bright and pure.
When the ground is bright, one should again focus the mind and contemplate the ground in front, imagining a lotus flower.
The flower has a thousand petals and is adorned with the seven treasures.
One should also imagine a sixteen-foot golden image, with the golden image sitting cross-legged, sitting on the lotus flower.
Having seen this image, one should carefully contemplate the flesh-top on the head.
Seeing the flesh-cone on the crown of the head, the hair is dark blue in color, each hair is stretched to a length of thirteen zhang, and when released, it turns to the right in a spiral.
There is a light of lapis lazuli residing above the Buddha's crown.
In this way, a hair curls and grows in each pore, and one observes the eighty-four thousand hairs, all making them clear and distinct.

Having seen this, next observe the image's face. The image's face is full, like the moon on the fifteenth day, and the majestic light becomes even more evident, with clear boundaries.ğŸ”½Further observe the broad and level forehead, and the tuft of white hair between the eyebrows, white like snow or a crystal pearl, turning to the right in a spiral.
Next, observe the image's nose, like a cast gold ingot, resembling an eagle's beak, located in the center of the face.
Next, observe the image's mouth. The lips are red and beautiful, like a bimba fruit.
Next, observe the image's teeth. There are forty teeth in the mouth, square, white, and even.
There are seals on the teeth, and light emerges from the seals, like white pearls.
The color between the teeth is red, emitting red light.
Next, contemplate the neck of the image, like a beryl tube, revealing the golden face.
Next, contemplate the chest of the image, with the virtue character and myriad character, the seal marks extremely clear, with light shining from the seals, complete with five colors.
Next, contemplate the Buddha image, with arms like an elephant king's trunk, soft and lovable.
Next, contemplate the hands of the image, with the ten fingers uneven, not losing their proper place.
The inside and outside of the hands grasp, with hair growing on the hands, like beryl light.
The hair is all upward-pointing, like red copper claws, with golden color on the claws.
The inside of the claws is red, like a red copper mountain combined with purple gold.
Next, contemplate the joined lotus palm, like a goose king, when extended it appears like a pearl net;
when the hands are retracted it is not seen.

After contemplating the hands of the image, next contemplate the body of the image, sitting squarely and peacefully like a true golden mountain, not leaning forward or backward, sitting in the middle just right.
Again, contemplate the shanks of the image, like a deer king's thighs, straight and full.

Next, contemplate the soles of the feet, flat and full, with a thousand spokes complete on the lotus under the feet, and hair growing on the feet like dark-blue lapis lazuli, the hair all pointing upward.
The toes are even, neither too long nor too short.
The nails are the color of red copper, and there are also thousand-spoked wheels on the tips of the toes, the spaces between the toes like a net, like the feet of a goose king.
Such features, as well as the bodily light, the halo, and the light from the neck, the light has transformed buddhas, many great bhiká¹£us, and many transformed bodhisattvas.
Such transformed people are like a whirling fire wheel, whirling and running after the light.
For the reverse contemplation, contemplate from the feet in reverse order up to the topknot;
For the forward contemplation, go from the top to the feet.
Contemplate the image like this, making the mind clear, focusing on seeing a single buddha image.
Having seen one image, one should further contemplate and be able to see two images.
When seeing the two Buddha images, the Buddha images' bodies become lapis lazuli emitting multi-colored light, the flames connecting like burning gold mountains, with countless transformed images.
After seeing the two images, he further sees three images.
After seeing the three images, he further sees four images.
After seeing the four images, he further sees five images.
After seeing the five images, he sees up to ten images.
After seeing the ten images, his mind becomes clearer and he sees JambudvÄ«pa within the four seas.
The mind of ordinary beings is narrow and cannot be expanded. If it is expanded, one should focus the mind and return to within the four seas, using Mount CakravÄá¸a as the boundary.
He sees within this ocean full of Buddha images, with the thirty-two marks and eighty minor marks all clearly distinct.
Each mark and minor mark has countless lights.
If within the many lights he sees each realm as mixed, impure, and unclean, it is due to karmic retribution.
One should also sweep the stÅ«pa again, anoint the ground, make pure counting rods, and humbly and respectfully perform various repentances.

One should also settle the mind in correct mindfulness in one place, as before contemplating the image, not relying on other matters, and carefully contemplating the space between the eyebrows of the image.
After contemplating the space between the eyebrows of the image, one should sequentially contemplate the other characteristics, making each excellent mark clear and distinct.
If it is not clear, one should again repent and perform various difficult tasks, and then concentrate the mind as before to contemplate the image.
Seeing the Buddha's body color and majestic appearance, with the thirty-two marks all complete, filling the four seas all sitting on flowers.
Having seen the seated image, one should further contemplate:

When the World-Honored One was in the world, he held his alms bowl and staff, entered the village to beg for food, traveled around to transform [beings], and used blessings to deliver sentient beings.
Today I only see seated images, not walking images.
What sins did I have in previous lives?
Having had this thought, he repented again.
After repenting, he again focused his mind and observed the image as before.
When observing the image, he saw all the seated images rise up, their huge bodies sixteen feet tall, upright and unmoving, their bodily characteristics and radiance all complete.
Having seen the images standing, he further saw the images walking, holding their alms bowls and staffs, their demeanor orderly, surrounded by celestial beings.
There were also many images flying in the sky, emitting golden light filling the sky, like golden clouds or golden mountains, their marks and characteristics incomparable.

They will also see various images performing the eighteen transformations in the sky, water flowing from the upper body and fire from the lower body, sometimes manifesting a huge body filling the sky, and then again becoming small like a mustard seed, walking on water as if on land, and walking on land as if on water, rising in the east and sinking in the west in the sky, rising in the west and sinking in the east, rising in the south and sinking in the north, rising in the north and sinking in the south, rising in the middle and sinking at the edges, rising at the edges and sinking in the middle, rising above and sinking below, and rising below and sinking above, walking, standing, sitting, and lying down freely as they wish.
Having seen these things, they should further think:
When the World-Honored One was in the world, he taught the monks to lie on their right sides.
I should now also observe the images lying down.
They will then see the images folding their saá¹ƒghÄá¹­Ä« robes, propping up their right elbows, and lying on their right sides.

Under his armpits, golden-colored beds naturally appear, with golden light sandalwood and various colored wonderful lotus flowers as bedding, above which jeweled curtains hang down with various necklaces.

The Buddha emits great light filling the jeweled curtains inside, like golden flowers, and also like stars and the moon. Countless jeweled lights are like massing clouds, clearly manifesting in the sky, with transformed Buddhas filling the sky.
After seeing the reclining image, one should further contemplate:

In the past there was a Buddha named Shakyamuni, who alone taught and transformed sentient beings, dwelling in this world for forty-nine years, entering great nirvana and attaining parinirvana, like firewood exhausted and fire extinguished, forever extinguished without remainder.ğŸ”½I now contemplate with my mind, and because of this contemplating mind I see these many images.
These many images come from nowhere and go nowhere, seen by my deluded mind alone.
As you contemplate in this way, the multitude of images will gradually disappear, and you will only see a single image sitting alone on a flower pedestal, cross-legged.
Contemplate this image carefully, clearly visualizing its thirty-two marks and eighty minor characteristics.
Seeing this image is called the method of contemplating the image.
The Buddha told Chan Nanti and ordered Ananda:

After the Buddha's nirvana, if bhiká¹£us, bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«s, upÄsakas, and upÄsikÄs wish to repent and eliminate their offenses, even though the Buddha is not present, those who focus their thoughts and contemplate the image will quickly attain purification from their evil offenses.
After contemplating this image, you should further contemplate a light emanating from the navel of the image.
The light is golden in color and divides into five branches:
one light illuminates to the left, one light illuminates to the right, one light illuminates in front, one light illuminates behind, and one light illuminates above.
In this way, above each of the five lights there are transformation Buddhas, the Buddha's features in sequence filling the entire sky.
When seeing these signs, make them extremely clear.
Again, see the transformation Buddhas reaching up to the Brahma world, filling the trichiliocosm.
In the trichiliocosm, see golden light like a purple gold mountain, unobstructed inside and out.
When seeing this, the mind and thoughts are delighted, seeing the seated image in front like the true shadow of the Buddha.
Having seen the Buddha's shadow, one should further think:
'This is just a shadow.
The World-Honored One's awesome spiritual power and wisdom are sovereign, manifesting this matter.
I should now contemplate the true Buddha.'
At that time, one will immediately see the Buddha's body as subtle as pure lapis lazuli, with vajra inside.
Within the vajra, there is purple golden light, mutually illuminating and manifesting the various excellent characteristics.
The thirty-two marks and eighty minor marks are like seal patterns, clearly and distinctly manifest, subtle and pure, beyond description.

Holding a water pot in his hand, he stands in the sky, the pot filled with water like nectar, the water five-colored, with five pure lights like beryl beads, soft and smooth, pouring on the practitioner's head and filling his body.
He sees in his own body that where the water touches, the eighty kinds of worms gradually wither and fall away.
When the worms have withered, the body becomes soft and supple, and the mind and thoughts are joyful and blissful.
He should think to himself:
The compassionate father Tathagata pours this Dharma water, the sweet dew, on the crown of my head.
This abhiseka Dharma is definitely not in vain.
At that time, he should further give rise to thoughts, thinking:
I only wish that the World-Honored One will expound the Dharma for me.
For those whose evil karma has been eliminated, they hear the Buddha expound the Dharma.

The Buddha's teachings are the four establishments of mindfulness, the four right efforts, the four bases of supernatural power, the five faculties, the five powers, the seven factors of awakening, and the eightfold noble path. These thirty-seven factors are explained one by one for practitioners.
After teaching these dharmas, he further teaches the contemplation of suffering, emptiness, impermanence, and non-self.
After teaching this dharma, because of seeing the Buddha and hearing the wonderful dharma, the mind opens up like water flowing downstream, and before long one also attains the path of arhatship.
Those with heavy karmic hindrances see the Buddha's mouth moving but do not hear the dharma, like a deaf person who hears nothing.
At that time, one should again practice repentance.

After repenting, one should prostrate with one's five limbs to the Buddha, weep in front of the Buddha, and spend many years cultivating various merits, and then one will finally hear the Buddha's teachings.
Although one hears the teachings, one does not understand the meaning.

He further sees the World-Honored One pouring the water from the ritual vase on the practitioner's head. The color of the water changes, becoming purely the color of vajra, entering from the crown. Its colors are each different, blue, yellow, red, and white, and various impure appearances are also manifested within it.
The water enters from the crown and goes straight down the body, exiting from the heels and flowing into the ground.
The ground immediately transforms into light, as large as a zhang, going down into the ground like this, gradually deepening until it reaches the water's edge.
Having reached the water's edge, one should further contemplate following this light.
Further contemplate this water, the pure emptiness below the water.

Further contemplate below the emptiness there is a lapis lazuli ground, below the lapis lazuli ground there is a golden ground, below the golden ground there is a vajra ground, and below the vajra ground one further sees emptiness.
Seeing this emptiness, it is suddenly vast emptiness, with nothing whatsoever.
Having seen this, further gather the mind and contemplate the image of a single Buddha as before.

At that time, the Buddha's light became even more radiant, indescribable, and he again held a water-filled ewer and poured water on the practitioner's head. The appearance and light of the water were also as described above.
In this way, it was done seven times.
The Buddha told Chanandinti:

This is called the samadhi of contemplating the image, also called the samadhi of mindfulness of the Buddha, also called the elimination of evil karma, and next called the salvation of those who violate the precepts.
It enables those who violate the precepts not to lose samadhi.
The Buddha told Ananda:

You should well receive and uphold this method of the abhiseka of the samadhi of contemplating the Buddha, and for the sake of all sentient beings in the future, you should extensively distinguish it.
When the Buddha spoke these words, the Venerable Chanandinti, the heavenly multitudes, and the 1,250 bhikshus all said:
The Tathagata, the World-Honored One, today spoke the Dharma for eliminating offenses for the sake of sentient beings with much distracted mind.
We only wish that the World-Honored One would further open the nectar, enabling sentient beings to attain the path of nirvana after the Buddha's extinction.

The bhiká¹£u Chanandanda, hearing the Buddha speak this samÄdhi of contemplating the Buddha, his body and mind were filled with joy, and he immediately attained innumerable samÄdhi gates. Suddenly his mind was enlightened, and he became an arhat, fully endowed with the three insights and six supernormal powers.
The Buddha told Ä€nanda:
The completion of this contemplation is called the nineteenth samÄdhi of contemplating the Buddha, also called the abhiá¹£eka method.
You should uphold it well and not forget it, and explain it extensively for all sentient beings in the future.
When the Buddha spoke these words, the assembly of bhiká¹£us, hearing what the Buddha said, joyfully undertook to follow it.
The Buddha told Ä€nanda:
Those with much lust, even if they attain this samÄdhi of contemplating the Buddha, it will be of no benefit, and they will not be able to obtain the noble path and fruits.
Next, one should further be taught to contemplate one's own body, causing it to be like the previous method, and to again create a skeleton, making it pure white like a snow mountain.

You should further focus your mind on the navel or waist, following the breath as it comes and goes. Count one and follow two, or count two and follow three, or count three and follow four, or count four and follow five, or count five and follow six, or count six and follow seven, or count seven and follow eight, or count eight and follow nine, or count nine and follow ten, starting over again. Follow the breath as it comes and goes until ten, then stop counting and rest.
At that time, the mind and thoughts will be tranquil and still, and you will see your own skin like a refined pouch.
Having seen this, you will not see the bones of the body or know the location of the mind.
At that time, you should further be taught to give rise to thoughts and make the mind and body within the body's limbs and joints like a jade person.
Having seen this, you should further focus your thoughts on the large joints above the waist and spine, causing the mind not to be scattered.
At that time, you will naturally see a bright appearance on your body, as large as a coin, gradually expanding, like the ear of a large fish, gathering everywhere like clouds.
It also resembles white clouds, and within the white clouds there is white light, like a crystal mirror, the light gradually increasing, the whole body clearly revealed.
There is also white light, round and equal, like a chariot wheel, bright inside and out, brighter than the sun.

When you see this, again as before, count one and follow two, or count two and follow three, or count three and follow four, or count four and follow five, or count five and follow six, or count six and follow seven, or count seven and follow eight, or count eight and follow nine, or count nine and follow ten, either singly or in pairs, the length of time is up to you.
In this way, focus your attention on the secret place, keeping your mind from wandering.
Again, focus your attention, as before, and observe the large joint in the waist.

When contemplating the great joints, the mind is still and unmoving, and one further sees one's body becoming even more radiant and vigorous, surpassing the previous by several times, like a large coin.

Doubling one's diligence, one further sees one's body becoming even more radiant and growing larger, like the mouth of a washbasin, with nothing in the world that can serve as a simile for its brightness.ğŸ”½Having seen this radiance, one redoubles one's diligence without slacking off, and further sees this radiance in front of one's chest, like a bright mirror.

When seeing this radiance, one should diligently apply oneself with single-minded concentration, like saving one's head from fire, earnestly and unceasingly, and one will see this radiance becoming even more abundant, with nothing in the world that can serve as a simile for it.
Its radiance is pure and free from impurities, with seven kinds of colored lights, the lights having the colors of the seven treasures, coming out from one's chest and entering into the radiance.
When this sign appears, one will greatly rejoice, naturally feeling blissful and at ease, with nothing in the world that can serve as a simile for it.

If one further diligently practices without slacking off, one will see light like clouds circling one's body seven times. Each light transforms into a light wheel, and within the light wheel one will naturally see the appearances of the twelve links of dependent origination.

If one is not diligent, lazy, and violates even minor precepts up to the duá¹£ká¹›ta offenses, if one sees the light as black like a wall, or sees this light like ash and charcoal, or sees this light resembling a worn-out robe, it is because one indulges in minor offenses that obstructs the sagely and uncontaminated light.
The Buddha told Ä€nanda:

This ablution Dharma door of the contemplation of impurity is the seed of all sages. It is commanded that bhiká¹£us, bhiká¹£uá¹‡Ä«s, upÄsakas, and upÄsikÄs who wish to cultivate the teachings of the sages should contemplate the impermanence, suffering, emptiness, and no-self of all phenomena, and like learning to count the breath, keep the mind from disturbance. They should diligently uphold the precepts and single-mindedly maintain them. Even in minor offenses, they should give rise to deep shame and remorse and repent. They should be cautious and not conceal even minor offenses.
If one conceals offenses, one will see all the light as if rotten wood.

When one sees this, one will know that one has violated the precepts. One should again feel shame and remorse, repent, and reproach oneself. One should sweep stÅ«pas, smear the ground, and do various difficult tasks. One should also make offerings and respectfully serve teachers, elders, and parents, regarding them as Buddhas and giving rise to utmost respect. One should further request great vows from one's teachers and parents, saying:
'I now make offerings to teachers, elders, and parents.
May I attain liberation in all my lives through this merit.'
Having cultivated merit with such shame and remorse, as before, count the breath and again see this radiant light, as lovely as before, no different.
You should further focus your thoughts and contemplate the large joints in the waist, with a stable mind and no scattered thoughts.
If the mind is still disturbed, you should again reproach yourself, feel ashamed, and repent.
After repenting, you will again see the light of the navel with the seven colors complete, like the seven treasures, and you should cause this light to merge into a single light, pure and lovely.
Having seen this, as before, you should be taught to focus your thoughts and contemplate the white skeleton person, white like a snow mountain.

Having seen the white bones, one should further be taught to fix one's thoughts and mind on the top of the skeleton, seeing the top of the skeleton naturally emitting light, the light very bright like the color of fire, the same size as a spear, hanging upside down from the top of the head, entering the skull, coming out from the skull, entering the neck bone, coming out from the neck bone, entering the chest bone, coming out from the chest bone, returning to enter the navel, coming out from the navel, immediately entering the large joint of the spine, having entered the large joint, the light immediately extinguishes.

When the light extinguishes, there immediately appears a great natural light cloud, adorned with various jewels, pure jeweled flowers, the best of colors, in the middle of which is a Buddha named ÅšÄkyamuni, fully endowed with the thirty-two marks and eighty minor marks,
each mark emitting a thousand lights, this light very bright, like the radiance of a billion suns blazing with flames.
That Buddha also expounded the four noble truths, and the light clearly remained in front of the practitioner, with his hand touching the practitioner's head.
The transformed Buddha further instructed:

In your previous lives, due to the causes and conditions of greed, anger, and delusion, you followed various evils, and because of the cover of ignorance, you have received bodies of birth and death life after life.
You should now contemplate the withered things within your body and the extinction of all fires outside your body.
Having said this, he again taught the method of contemplating impurity as before, contemplating the worms in the body all withered and falling.
Having seen this, he should further arouse fire to burn the worms to death.
When the worms did not die, he further saw his body like white crystal, naturally fresh and white.

Having seen the white bones, light emerges from the head. The size and coarseness of the light is like a spear, five feet long. One should further contemplate, causing the head to turn back, and further contemplate, causing the head to turn back, causing the whole body to fall back, with the head leaning against the spine, facing the large joint of the navel.

Having seen this, one should further contemplate carefully, causing the person of white bones to be the same color as the light.ğŸ”½Having become the same color, one sees various colored fruits on the tip of the light.
Having seen these fruits, one further sees various lights emerging from the top of the fruits.
There is white light, the light is extremely bright, like a white jeweled cloud.
These skeletons are the same color as the light, without any difference.

One further sees the bones collapsing and falling, some with the head falling to the ground, some with the bone joints each scattered, some with the whole body of white bones, like a fierce wind blowing rain and snow gathering and dispersing unpredictably, like lightning flashing on and off.
These skeletons fall to the ground and gather together like a mound, resembling rotten sawdust piled in one place.
The practitioner observes himself seeing a natural qi emerge from the mound, reaching into the void like smoke and clouds, its color fresh and white, filling the void.
It rotates to the right and then gathers back into a single place.
When seeing this, he should further be taught to contemplate a single skeleton.
He sees this skeleton with a body of nine colors, the nine lines distinct, with nine-colored skeletons in each line, their colors fresh and vivid, indescribable.
Each skeleton should also be made to have a complete body, shining and manifesting within the previous skeleton, without obstruction.
Having made this contemplation, he should further contemplate each color as if made of lapis lazuli, without any obstruction.
Within that color, there are ninety-nine colors, and in each color there are nine colors of numerous skeletons.
These skeleton people have various appearances, their natures are different, and they do not obstruct each other.
Having seen this, one should diligently cultivate to extinguish all evil.
Having seen this, the previously gathered light clouds come in like a clay vessel and enter one's body through the navel.
Having entered the navel, they enter the spine.
Having entered the spine, one sees one's own body as originally no different, restored to its former state.
In and out of meditation, due to counting the breath, one always sees the above matters.

When seeing this, one should again teach oneself to focus the mind and abide in the light at the navel, not allowing the mind to be scattered. At that time, the mind and thoughts are extremely peaceful and secure.
Having become peaceful and secure, one should further learn to carefully discern the noble liberations. At that time, one will again see the seven buddhas of the past expounding the Dharma for them.
As for expounding the Dharma, it means expounding the four noble truths and the five aggregates of clinging as empty and without self.

At that time, the buddhas and sages always come before the practitioner and teach various dharmas, also teaching the contemplation of emptiness, no-self, no-action, and the samÄdhi of no-aspiration, and say:
'Dharma child!

You should now contemplate carefully that form, sound, smell, taste, and touch are all impermanent and cannot last long, fleeting like lightning and immediately changing, also like an illusion, like a mirage, like a gandharva city, like what is seen in a dream but is not known when one awakens, like the light seen when drilling for fire that disappears in an instant, like the trace of a bird flying in the sky that cannot be sought, like an echo that has no one to respond to it.
You should now contemplate in this way, and the three realms are like an illusion and also like a transformation.'
Here, one immediately sees that inside and outside the body, there is emptiness and nothing, like a bird flying in the sky with no support, and the mind transcends the three realms.
Contemplating the world, Mount Sumeru, and the great oceans, all are not long-lasting, also like illusions and transformations.
Contemplating one's own body, not seeing the characteristics of the body, one then thinks like this:
'The world is impermanent, the three realms are unstable, and everything is empty.
Where is there a body?
And the various forms and desires that the eyes encounter, as well as all women, arise from inversion, mistakenly seen as lovable, but in reality, they are quickly decaying and deteriorating dharmas.
The body of a woman is like shackles and chains, exhausting people's consciousness.
Foolish men are attached to them, not knowing to be content, unable to extricate themselves, not avoiding handcuffs, not breaking free from shackles.'

The practitioner, having already recognized the characteristics of dharmas and knowing that dharmas are empty and tranquil, these various forms and desires are like enemies and thieves. How can one be attached to them?
They are also like a prison that is solid and difficult to abandon.
I now contemplate emptiness, detaching from the three realms. Contemplating the world is like bubbles on water, quickly disappearing, the mind without various thoughts.

One should know that worldly dharmas are heavy afflictions. Ordinary beings are deluded and do not realize this until death. They do not know the myriad sufferings and are attached to them, unable to escape. Indulging in madness, they go to extremes.
I now observe this mad infatuation with women's beauty, like an echo or a reflection in a mirror, sought but unobtainable.
Observing this beauty, where is it?
False views harm and deceive ordinary beings, causing much harm.
Now observing this beauty, it is like a mad flower that falls with the wind, coming from nowhere and going nowhere. It is illusory and unreal, yet foolish men delight in it.
Now observing this beauty, all of it is impermanent, like a leper cured by a good doctor.
I now observe suffering, emptiness, and impermanence, and see that these forms and appearances are all without substance.

I think of ordinary beings as very pitiful. They love and cling to these forms, respecting them without weariness. They indulge in delusion and attachment, enjoying them endlessly. For the sake of affection and love, they become slaves. The spear of desire pierces themselves, pain penetrating to the marrow of their hearts. The shackles of affection and love bind their bodies.
Having thought like this, he further contemplates that everything is completely empty and tranquil.
All these desires and emotional states of the various forms arise from the five aggregates and the four elements.
The five aggregates have no owner, and the four elements have no self. Their natures and characteristics are both empty. How can they exist?

When contemplating like this, wisdom becomes evident. The body appears brightly, like a maá¹‡i jewel without obstruction. It is like the essence of vajra, blue and white, clearly manifest, like a deer breaking through the encirclement to escape the hunter's harm and suffering.

Contemplate that the nature and characteristics of the five aggregates are all pure, contemplate the six great elements as a bird soaring high without relying on anything, swallow the hook of form and look up and down to attain liberation, be free from all female desires and never give rise to emotions again, and naturally transcend the ocean of lust.
All afflictions are like a group of fish competing to follow and fall into a dark pit.
Ignorance and old age and death are burned by the fire of wisdom.
Contemplate that form is mixed, defiled, ugly, and impure, like an illusion that does not last for a moment, be forever free from the defilements of form and not be bound by form.
The Buddha told Ä€nanda:
